text:
Q: How do I build Kismet Debugger as described by the developer? A:

RE-UE4SS requirements includes:

  • Rust toolchain 1.73.0 or greater

You have to install rust.

Q: Helm: get list of the keys in a map A:

Helm includes a number of extension functions, and among these is a keys function that does exactly what you ask: given a dict-type object (like .Values) it returns its keys as a list.

For the overall structure of the Helm template you show, remember that it's possible to construct additional values files and pass them using helm install -f and similar options; you don't have to put every possible setting for every possible environment in the single values.yaml file. I might create a separate file per environment:

# values-preview.yaml
server: https://sds
something: adkfgdf

# values-staging.yaml
server: https://35.246.225.83

Now if you, for example, helm install -f values-staging.yaml, then .Values.server will expand to the configured location of the server, without any of the complex conditional logic you show.

Q: ClusterAuthorizationException in Kafka while creating topic A:

ClusterAuthorizationFailed may indicate that your client is configured to attempt an operation that it doesn't have permission to do from the server.

Namely, allow.auto.create.topics and enable.idempotence are both set to true by default, and the server can be configured to disallow those, leading you to an extremely misleading error message of ClusterAuthorizationFailed.

This page in the docs may help you find other settings that could lead to you getting that error:

https://kafka.apache.org/documentation/#operations_resources_and_protocols

Q: dynamically open dropdown in vue A:

Call focus() and set isMenuActive = true

Q: Why can't the operator()() be invoked on the mt19937 object? A:

rng is a random number engine. Its operator() returns some numbers, one per call. So rng() is a number.

uni is a random number distribution. Given a random number engine, its operator() produces pseudorandom numbers from a specific distribution. Given a number, it produces a compilation error.
